channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Iceland Premier, Named in Panama Papers, Says He’s Not Quitting
item.description: Prime Minister Sigmundur David Gunnlaugsson said he had stepped down amid the scandal only for an “unspecified” period.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Prime Minister Sigmundur David Gunnlaugsson of Iceland at the residence of President Olafur Ragnar Grimsson in Reykjavik after a meeting on Tuesday.

item.title: E.U. Introduces Proposals to Overhaul Asylum System
item.description: The measures would create a mechanism to deal with exceptional situations in which a country is facing an influx, or establish a permanent system to redistribute migrants.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: Migrants on the Greek island of Chios on Wednesday.

item.title: Model in Gucci Ad Is Deemed ‘Unhealthily Thin’ by British Regulator
item.description: The ruling by the Advertising Standards Authority fanned a perennial debate in the fashion industry about what constitutes underweight.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Sinosphere: Signing Up Organ Donors in China Can Be an Uphill Battle
item.description: About 300,000 Chinese people require transplants each year, and voluntary donation, while growing, still falls far short of meeting that need.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: People wept as they paid their respects to deceased relatives in front of a monument bearing the names of organ donors ahead of the Qingming Festival on Monday, when Chinese honor their dead.

item.title: Cambodia to Bring Wild Tigers From Abroad in Fight Against Extinction
item.description: A small number of the animals will be taken to the Mondulkiri Protected Forest, the last place in the country one was seen.
item.category: International Union for Conservation of Nature
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: A tiger at the Phnom Tamao Wildlife Rescue Center in the Cambodian province of Takeo last year.

item.title: Moshe Katsav, Jailed Ex-President of Israel, Loses Bid for Early Release
item.description: Mr. Katsav, who is serving a seven-year term for rape, had requested that his sentence be reduced by a third for good behavior.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Jerusalem Journal: Risk of Collapse at Jesus’ Tomb Unites Rival Christians
item.description: Three branches of Christianity are undertaking a $3.4 million renovation of the shrine holding Jesus’ tomb in the Church of the Holy Sepulcher in Jerusalem.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID
item.media:description: The shrine holding the tomb of Jesus in Jerusalem’s Old City. The shrine, an unsteady 206-year-old structure held together by an iron cage, has become an uncomfortable symbol of Christian divisions.

item.title: North Korea May Roll Out Rocket System With Greater Reach, South Says
item.description: The weapon, which could be used as soon as this year, would expand the North’s ability to hit South Korean and American military forces in the South, the defense minister said.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: North Korean surveillance cameras atop a steel tower peer into the South, near the border village of Panmunjom.

item.title: Sinosphere: Architect of China’s ‘Great Firewall’ Bumps Into It
item.description: During a presentation on digital security, the architect, Fang Binxing, was forced to use location-masking software to reach websites in South Korea.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: People at an Internet bar in Beijing. China’s system of Internet controls, known as the Great Firewall, blocks access to certain foreign websites.

item.title: Raw Data: To Beat Go Champion, Google’s Program Needed a Human Army
item.description: Without the multitude of minds that created a program capable of beating a Go game master, the contest would have been a no-go.
item.dc:creator: GEORGE JOHNSON
item.media:description: Lee Se-dol, a professional Go player from South Korea, was smiling amid other players despite losing four of five games against a Google computer program called AlphaGo.

item.title: Brazil’s Congress Must Consider Impeaching Vice President
item.description: A justice on Brazil’s high court ruled that an impeachment request made against Michel Temer must be considered by Congress while it holds hearings about removing the president.
item.dc:creator: VINOD SREEHARSHA

item.title: Iceland’s Prime Minister Steps Down Amid Panama Papers Scandal
item.description: The departure of Sigmundur David Gunnlaugsson is the most prominent fallout from the leaked papers. Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain is also battling revelations that involve his family.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER, STEPHEN CASTLE and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Armenia and Azerbaijan Halt Fighting on Border
item.description: A cease-fire between Armenians and Azerbaijanis has put to rest, for now, fears that the conflict over the disputed Nagorno-Karabakh region might spiral into a wider war.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: A funeral on Tuesday in Yerevan, Armenia, for a service member killed in clashes over Nagorno-Karabakh in Azerbaijan.

item.title: Italian Official Warns Egypt Over Inquiry Into Student’s Death
item.description: A slow-moving investigation into the killing, hampered by troubled cooperation between Italian and Egyptian police, has prompted Italian accusations of an Egyptian cover-up.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH and NOUR YOUSSEF

item.title: Editorial: The Panama Papers’ Sprawling Web of Corruption
item.description: The leaked files reveal an industry that flourishes in the gaps and holes of international finance.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: The Panama Papers: Here’s What We Know
item.description: The documents name international politicians, business leaders and celebrities in a web of unseemly financial transactions.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK
item.media:description: Sigmundur David Gunnlaugsson addressing the Icelandic Parliament in Reykjavik on Monday. He offered his resignation as prime minister on Tuesday.

item.title: How a Cryptic Message, ‘Interested in Data?,’ Led to the Panama Papers
item.description: “We’re very interested,” replied an investigative reporter at a German newspaper in response to an email more than a year ago from an anonymous whistle-blower.
item.dc:creator: NICOLA CLARK
item.media:description: Bastian Obermayer, left, and Frederik Obermaier, two of the journalists at Süddeutsche Zeitung, who began investigating the Panama Papers more than a year ago.

item.title: Taliban Leader, Trying to End Infighting, Appoints Critics to Senior Posts
item.description: The appointments of the son and brother of Mullah Muhammad Omar, the Taliban founder, come at a time of rising criticism and the threat of outright rebellion from field commanders.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and TAIMOOR SHAH
item.media:description: Mullah Akhtar Muhammad Mansour’s focus on consolidating his rule is bad news for the Afghan government, which had hoped to use the divisions among the Taliban to bring them to the negotiating table.

item.title: Italians, Helped by an App, Translate the Talmud
item.description: The first volume of the first Italian translation of the Babylonian Talmud took dozens of scholars, linguists, philologists and editors five years to complete.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:description: Consisting of 5,422 pages of Hebrew and Aramaic, the Babylonian Talmud originally completed 1,500 years ago has defied widespread translation.

item.title: Washington Memo: As an Investor, Osama bin Laden Was Bullish on Gold
item.description: An order to buy gold bars and coins with ransom money was in a letter that was part of the trove seized by Navy SEALs at Bin Laden’s hide-out in Pakistan.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:description: “Ten tolas,” the denomination of gold bars that Osama bin Laden instructed Al Qaeda’s general manager to acquire in 2010.
